Teaser: Intralesional Mycobacterium w vaccine appears to be as effective as imiquimod cream for treating anogenital warts, researchers from India report.

Headlines: Vaccine Discussions: It's All in How You Frame the Benefits
Teaser: Parents were more likely to vaccinate their infants against measles, mumps, and rubella when told how their child would personally benefit than if they hear about immunization's benefit to society.

Headlines: Exclusive: NewLink Says Ebola Vaccine Trial Could Start in Weeks
Teaser: NewLink Genetics Corp, which licensed an Ebola vaccine developed by Canadian government scientists, has enough doses on hand to launch the first human safety trial of an Ebola vaccine this summer.

Headlines: BCG-TB Vaccination May Be Delayed for HIV-Exposed Infants
Teaser: A South African study has found no evidence suggesting that delayed BCG vaccination in HIV-exposed infants compromises immune responses to the vaccine.

Headlines: U.S. Advisory Panel Recommends Prevnar 13 Vaccine for Elderly
Teaser: An influential U.S. medical advisory panel recommended that people 65 and older be given Pfizer Inc's blockbuster Prevnar 13 vaccine to protect against pneumococcal bacteria that can cause pneumonia and other infections.

Headlines: Idaho Reports Alarming Rise in Whooping Cough Cases
Teaser: Idaho health officials urged vaccination to combat what they said was an alarming rise this year in the number of cases of whooping cough, which has killed an infant and afflicted 240 other state residents since January.

Headlines: Influenza: High-Dose Vaccine Decreases Flu in Older Adults
Teaser: High-dose vaccine improved antibody responses and reduced illness among persons aged 65 years and older compared with standard-dose vaccine in a randomized blinded trial.

Headlines: U.S. Emergency Labs Ready to Work on Ebola Drugs If Asked
Teaser: All three U.S. facilities established to quickly make vaccines and therapeutics in the event of a major public health threat say they are standing by to support any U.S. government effort to scale up a treatment for Ebola.

Headlines: Clinical Trial to Start Soon on GSK Ebola Vaccine
Teaser: A clinical trial of an experimental vaccine against the deadly Ebola virus is set to start shortly, according to British drugmaker GlaxoSmithKline, which is co-developing the product with U.S. scientists.

Headlines: Viral Reservoir Seen 'Strikingly' Soon After HIV Infection
Teaser: A reservoir of HIV is established much sooner after infection than was previously thought; measuring that reservoir is the next big challenge.

Headlines: Use of Some Preventive Care Services Low Despite ACA
Teaser: Patients were more likely to receive services if they had insurance, but use overall was less than 50% for HIV tests and for vaccines for influenza and shingles.

Headlines: New Kennedy Book Calls for Thimerosal-Free Vaccines
Teaser: A new book about the safety of thimerosal in vaccines attempts to reopen a question that public health authorities consider settled. Robert Kennedy Jr. is the editor. But who are the authors?

Headlines: Ebola Virus: How Contagious?
Teaser: Two Americans stricken with the Ebola virus amid a record outbreak in West Africa are now being treated in Atlanta, which has triggered fears of a potential outbreak in the United States.

Headlines: Ebola Emergency Turns Spotlight on Experimental Drugs
Teaser: With hundreds of patients in Africa suffering the devastating effects of Ebola, health experts are scrambling to determine which drugs might offer the best experimental treatment.

Headlines: WHO Consulting Ethics Experts on Experimental Ebola Drugs
Teaser: The use of an experimental drug to treat two U.S. charity workers infected with Ebola virus has prompted the World Health Organization to consider the implications of making such treatments more widely available.

Headlines: FDA OKs Menactra as Booster Against Meningococcal Disease
Teaser: Menactra (Sanofi Pasteur) is indicated in individuals 15 to 55 years of age for booster vaccination against meningococcal disease caused by Neisseria meningitidis serogroups A, C, Y, and W-135.

Headlines: Experimental Interventions Invited on Ebola Frontline
Teaser: Relaxed restrictions on experimental Ebola interventions, recently announced by the World Health Organization, are welcome news.

Headlines: Virus May Predispose People to Appendicitis
Teaser: The adenovirus was found in 14% of patients who had an appendectomy, say researchers.

Headlines: Random Biopsy on Negative Colposcopy Detects More Disease
Teaser: Random biopsy at the transformation zone in women in whom cervical lesions could not be visualized on colposcopy detected additional high-grade disease, especially in those positive for HPV 16 or 18.

Headlines: Ebola Outbreak 'Perfect Storm' According to CDC
Teaser: 'A perfect storm' of challenges came together to create the current outbreak of the virus in West Africa that is being called the worst Ebola outbreak in history.

Headlines: Be on Lookout for Enterovirus-D68, CDC Says
Teaser: The CDC is investigating whether the rare virus is responsible for outbreaks of respiratory illness among children in 11 states. So far the agency has not received reports of neurological complications.

Headlines: UN to Set Up Ebola Crisis Center, Stop Spread in 6-9 Months
Teaser: The United Nations plans to set up an Ebola crisis center to coordinate the response to the deadly virus and to strive to halt its spread in West African countries in six to nine months, U.N. Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon announced.

Headlines: WHO Urges Drug Companies, Regulators to Speed Ebola Work
Teaser: The World Health Organization (WHO) called for pharmaceutical companies and regulatory agencies to work together to accelerate development of safe and efficient drugs and vaccines against Ebola.

Headlines: U.N. Says USD 600 mln Needed to Tackle Ebola as Toll Tops 1,900
Teaser: The United Nations said it would take $600 million in supplies to control an outbreak of Ebola in West Africa as the death toll from the worst ever epidemic of the virus topped 1,900 and Guinea warned it had penetrated a new part of the country.

Headlines: Chimerix Says Antiviral Shows Promise Against Ebola
Teaser: Chimerix Inc said its lead experimental drug showed promise against the deadly Ebola virus in laboratory testing at the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the National Institutes of Health.

Headlines: Vaccines Lead to Decline in Complex Otitis Media Incidence
Teaser: Recurrent, nonresponsive otitis media caused by any pneumococcal strain fell 77% with the introduction of pneumococcal vaccines, according to a new study.

Headlines: CDC Consolidates HPV Vaccine Recommendations
Teaser: The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention published consolidated guidelines on human papilloma virus (HPV) vaccination in the August 29 Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report.

Headlines: Wanted: 60 Volunteers to Test Ebola Vaccine in Middle England
Teaser: Fancy testing an Ebola vaccine? It may sound scary but the scientist behind the British trial of a shot that has so far only been given to monkeys sees little risk and is optimistic he will drum up enough volunteers.

Headlines: Vaccination Coverage High Overall, but Varies by State
Teaser: A CDC report details vaccination coverage for 2013; coverage remains high but varies greatly by state.

Headlines: NIH to Begin Ebola Vaccine Trial in Humans
Teaser: The first Ebola virus vaccine trial will begin next week, using a bivalent vaccine, to be followed by other trials in the coming months, according to the National Institutes of Health.

Headlines: Canada's Immunovaccine Inc Says Test of Ebola Vaccine Promising
Teaser: Four monkeys survived the Ebola virus after being injected with a vaccine that included Immunovaccine Inc's technology, the tiny Canadian company said.

Headlines: ICAAC to Showcase 'Extraordinary' Ebola Efforts
Teaser: From the emergence of new infections to the resurgence of old ones, the 54th Interscience Conference on Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy will explore new ways to fight bugs.

Headlines: Sierra Leone 'Hero' Doctor's Death Exposes Slow Ebola Response
Teaser: When two American aid workers recovered from Ebola after being treated with an experimental drug, the grieving family of Sierra Leone's most famous doctor wondered why he had been denied the same treatment before he died from the deadly virus.

Headlines: Ebola Therapies and Vaccines Need Priority, Support
Teaser: Editorials published this week by major infectious disease experts call for support and prioritizing development of Ebola therapies and vaccines while maintaining momentum in controlling the outbreak.

Headlines: Polio: 2 Vaccines Together May Be Key to Full Eradication
Teaser: A new study has provided a scientific basis for boosting live attenuated oral poliovirus vaccine with a dose of inactivated poliovirus.

Headlines: Scientists Grapple With Ethics in Rush to Release Ebola Vaccines
Teaser: Normally it takes years to prove a new vaccine is both safe and effective before it can be used in the field. But with hundreds of people dying a day in the worst ever outbreak of Ebola, there is no time to wait.

Headlines: WHO Sees Small-Scale Use of Ebola Vaccines in January
Teaser: The WHO said it expected to begin small-scale use of two experimental Ebola vaccines in West Africa early next year and in the meantime, transfusions of survivors' blood may offer the best hope of treatment.

Headlines: Poor Coordination Bogging Down Ebola Vaccine Shipment
Teaser: Poor global coordination has bogged down Canada's efforts to deliver its Ebola vaccine to Africa, a Canadian minister said on Thursday, six weeks after Ottawa offered to make a donation to help fight the deadly outbreak.

Headlines: Experts Unveil Plan to End Rabies Globally via Dog Vaccinations
Teaser: Rabies experts unveiled a blueprint for eliminating the pernicious disease, which almost always is caused by bites from rabid dogs and kills tens of thousands of people a year worldwide, through a program of mass dog vaccinations in targeted regions.

Headlines: Tdap Uptake Low in Publicly Insured Pregnant Women
Teaser: Only ~14% of publicly insured pregnant women in Michigan are receiving Tdap vaccination, despite an ACIP recommendation, a new study has found.

Headlines: Inovio to Start Human Trials of Ebola Vaccine
Teaser: Vaccine developer Inovio Pharmaceuticals Inc said the company and its partner GeneOne Life Science Inc will start testing its experimental Ebola vaccine in humans in the first half of 2015.

Headlines: Most Vaccination-Onset Epilepsy Has Genetic, Structural Cause
Teaser: A new study shows that most seizures beginning after vaccination have an underlying genetic or structural cause, which should increase faith in vaccine safety, researchers say.

Headlines: Ebola Cases Could Rise to 1.4 Million in 4 Months, CDC Says
Teaser: In 2 new reports, the CDC and WHO have broken down the latest numbers for Ebola epidemic; a surge in containment would reduce the total number of cases but must begin immediately.

Headlines: Chikungunya Virus Concern Growing
Teaser: Experts express growing concern about the spread of chikungunya virus, alert providers about its presentation, diagnosis, and management.

Headlines: Scientists See Risk of Mutant Airborne Ebola as Remote
Teaser: The Ebola virus raging through West Africa is mutating rapidly as it tears a deadly path through cities, towns and villages, but the genetic changes are for now not giving it the ability to spread more easily.

Headlines: Flu Vaccine Coverage for Healthcare Workers Still Lacking
Teaser: To increase influenza vaccination coverage among healthcare personnel and lower the risk for influenza for them and their patients, comprehensive vaccination strategies are needed.

Headlines: Influenza Vaccination Up in Kids, Holds Steady in Adults
Teaser: At a briefing today, the CDC director advised docs to 'make it easy' for patients to receive the vaccine in their offices and to make sure they get themselves, as well as get their staffs vaccinated.

Headlines: First UK Volunteer Gets GSK Ebola Vaccine in Trial
Teaser: The first volunteer in a fast-tracked British safety trial of an experimental Ebola vaccine made by GlaxoSmithKline received the injection on Wednesday, trial organizers said.

Headlines: Ebola, Marburg DNA Vaccines Prove Safe in Phase 1 Trial
Teaser: Protection from a 3-dose series waned but was improved by a booster.

Headlines: Ebola Vaccine Trial Finds 'No Red Flags': U.S. Senate Testimony
Teaser: A key safety trial of an experimental Ebola vaccine manufactured by GlaxoSmithKline has injected 10 healthy volunteers since Sept. 2, and so far 'no red flags' indicating serious adverse reactions have been found.

Headlines: Urine HPV Test as Alternative to Cervical Smear
Teaser: A simple urine test to screen for HPV is less invasive and may be more acceptable to women, but further evaluation is needed.

Headlines: 'Cocooning' Reduces Whooping Cough Risk in Infants
Teaser: A case-control study has shown moderate protection against laboratory-confirmed pertussis in infants whose parents received Tdap boosters.

Headlines: Ebola Highlights Slow Progress in War on Tropical Diseases
Teaser: Some of the world's most gruesome diseases are finally getting a bit of attention.

Headlines: WHO Mandates New Single-Use Syringe
Teaser: A British inventor's syringe and lab tests that get quick results with only a drop of blood are among the low-cost innovations broadening access to healthcare globally.

Headlines: Gates Foundations Pledges USD 50 mln to Fight Ebola Epidemic
Teaser: The Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation pledged $50 million to support emergency efforts to contain West Africa's Ebola epidemic, which has already killed almost 2,300 people in the worst outbreak of the virus in history.

Headlines: WHO Expects Around 200,000 Ebola Vaccine Doses by Mid-2015
Teaser: The World Health Organization (WHO) set out plans for speeding up development and deployment of experimental Ebola vaccines, saying hundreds of thousands of doses should be ready for use in West Africa by the middle of 2015.

Headlines: Occupation, Socioeconomic Status Tied to Legionellosis Risk
Teaser: A New York City study has found that poverty and jobs in transportation, protection services, cleaning, and construction increased the risk for Legionnaires' disease.

Headlines: H3N2 Influenza Outbreak Among Vaccinated Sailors
Teaser: A quarter of the sailors on a US Navy minesweeper developed influenza A infection even though 99% of them had been vaccinated, highlighting the risk for outbreak in vaccinated, healthy, young persons.

Headlines: No Long-Term MS Risk After Vaccination
Teaser: A new study finds no association with multiple sclerosis up to 3 years following vaccination, but it did uncover a risk for demyelinating syndromes in patients under age 50 in the first few weeks after being vaccinated.

Headlines: Illness in Preschoolers Can Forecast Outbreaks
Teaser: A biosurveillance program for preschools and childcare centers might be able to predict outbreaks in the larger community, report researchers

Headlines: Home Care Kits Highlight Gaps in West Africa's Ebola Response
Teaser: With the number of Ebola cases spiraling in West Africa and weeks remaining until treatment units promised by Western governments are built, health workers fighting one of the world's deadliest diseases are being forced to improvise.

Headlines: Large, Nationwide Study Links Enterovirus to Type 1 Diabetes
Teaser: Could a vaccine be developed to help prevent type 1 diabetes? A new nationwide study from Taiwan provides further evidence of an infectious etiology         for some cases.

Headlines: China Military-Linked Firm Eyes Quick Approval of Ebola Drug
Teaser: A Chinese drugmaker with close military ties is seeking fast-track approval for a drug that it says can cure Ebola, as China joins the race to help treat a deadly outbreak of the disease.

Headlines: 'What Can I Do to Reduce My Risk for Cancer?'
Teaser: A new European Code Against Cancer spells out in simple language steps that individuals can take to reduce their risk for cancer.

Headlines: Pneumococcal Vaccine Protects More Than Just Kids Who Get It
Teaser: Since the introduction of PCV13, a 13-valent pediatric vaccine, the number of cases of invasive pneumococcal disease has declined, as has the antibiotic resistance of vaccine strains.

Headlines: Adjuvant Boosts Supply of Avian Flu Vaccine
Teaser: In a pandemic situation, it would be possible to immunize eight times as many people with a limited supply of H7N9 vaccine, report researchers.

Headlines: Vaccination, Early Flu Treatment Critical for Pregnant Women
Teaser: Pregnant women who developed 2009 H1N1 influenza were sicker and their infants had worse outcomes, an analysis of data from the 2009 H1N1 influenza pandemic and the 2013-2014 flu season has shown.

Headlines: Experts Prioritize Two Ebola Vaccines, Map Early Trial Plans
Teaser: Phase 1 trials of two vaccine candidates are currently underway to determine immunogenicity outcomes in humans.

Headlines: HIV's Mechanism Could Guide AIDS Vaccine, Study Finds
Teaser: New research on the mechanisms by which HIV infects cells provides insights that could potentially guide the development of a vaccine against the virus, according to U.S. government and other scientists.

Headlines: Ebola Outbreak and Enterovirus in the Limelight at IDWeek
Teaser: Conference attendees will hear expert perspectives and advice and learn about infection prevention and control.

Headlines: CDC Reports on Neurologic Disease Clusters
Teaser: Cases of acute neurologic illness of unknown etiology in Colorado children come on the heels of a cluster of acute flaccid paralysis with anterior myelitis among mostly young people in California.

Headlines: Stick to Standard Anthrax Vaccine Doses: Study
Teaser: Reduced doses of anthrax vaccine (AVA, BioThrax) may not provide the same level of post-exposure prophylaxis as does a full dose, according to researchers.

Headlines: CDC Investigating Four Deaths Linked to Enterovirus D68
Teaser: One death was confirmed yesterday by the Rhode Island Department of Health in a child who died of Staphylococcus aureus sepsis associated with EV-D68.

Headlines: GSK, NewLink Working to Bring Ebola Vaccines Online
Teaser: Both GlaxoSmithKline and NewLink Genetics are working to boost their capacity to make Ebola vaccines, with a goal of a 'very significant increase in scale during the first half of 2015,' the WHO said.

Headlines: Paralysis in Children With Enterovirus D68
Teaser: Some children hospitalized with breathing problems caused by enterovirus D68 in Colorado and Kansas City have also developed unexplained paralysis in their arms and legs, officials say.

Headlines: Travel Restrictions Slow, but Do Not Stop, Pandemic
Teaser: Sealing international borders delayed the spread and peak of influenza pandemics, but on its own, it could not prevent the dissemination of influenza.

Headlines: Less Effective Vaccine May Mean More Severe Influenza Season
Teaser: Antivirals to treat infections will be more important given an influenza A virus that has antigenically drifted from the version used in the seasonal vaccine.

Headlines: Pertussis Cases Near 10,000 in California This Year
Teaser: Through November 26, there were 9935 cases of pertussis with onset in 2014 reported in California, highlighting the need for vaccination of pregnant women in their third trimester.

Headlines: MERS-CoV Spread Appears Because of Infection Control Lapses
Teaser: Healthcare-associated outbreaks are important in fueling the MERS-CoV epidemic in Arabian Peninsula countries, highlighting the need to improve infection control in affected areas.

Headlines: EU Agency Says No Evidence Novartis Flu Vaccine Caused Deaths
Teaser: There is no evidence that Novartis's flu vaccine Fluad caused serious events including deaths in Italy, experts at the European Medicines Agency said.

Headlines: Many IBD Patients Don't Get Hepatitis B Vaccine: US Study
Teaser: Most patients with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) do not receive screening for or vaccination against hepatitis B virus (HBV), according to a new study looking at a large tertiary gastroenterology practice.

Headlines: Herpes Vaccine Safe in Patients With Arthritis on Biologics
Teaser: Patients with autoimmune and inflammatory diseases are more prone to getting herpes zoster than the general population, but these patients can be safely vaccinated, a new study has suggested.

Headlines: Older High-Risk Children Should Receive PCV13, AAP Says
Teaser: At-risk children aged 6 to 18 years should receive PCV13, even if they have received other pneumococcal vaccines, according to a new recommendation from the American Academy of Pediatrics.

Headlines: GPs Have Many Misconceptions About Allergies
Teaser: General physicians who are not board-certified in allergy and immunology have knowledge gaps that need to be corrected for patient safety, report investigators.

Headlines: Legislation Fails to Boost HPV Vaccine Uptake
Teaser: Rates of vaccination for the human papillomavirus (HPV) hover around 45% for adolescent girls and 10% for boys, regardless of whether state legislation encourages immunization.

Headlines: Pertussis Vaccine Appears Safe in Pregnancy for Mom, Baby
Teaser: Pregnant women who receive the pertussis vaccine are not at increased risk of adverse birth outcomes, according to new findings published in JAMA.

Headlines: Measles Eradication Efforts Wane, Will Not Meet 2015 Goals
Teaser: A substantial increase in cases between 2012 and 2013 and reduced vaccination programs put prior gains at risk, the WHO and the CDC warn.

Headlines: Review Finds Flu Shot Is Still a Good Choice for Seniors
Teaser: The seasonal flu vaccine protects seniors during so-called epidemic seasons, when flu is widespread, according to a review of past studies.

Headlines: Low HPV Vaccine Uptake Rates in All the Wrong States
Teaser: HPV vaccine uptake rates are lowest in states with the highest rates of cervical cancer incidence and mortality, and patterns are on track to keep incidence rates high.

Headlines: Pneumococcal Vaccine Reduces Hospitalization Rates
Teaser: Young children's hospitalizations for sinusitis and pneumonia decreased in the years after pneumococcal vaccine introduction in Sweden.

Headlines: Chikungunya: Clinicians Should Caution Travelers, CDC Says
Teaser: Clinicians should recommend mosquito bite prevention for patients traveling to the Caribbean and should consider this disease for differential diagnosis in patients who have traveled recently.

Headlines: New Hepatitis C Vaccine May Overcome Previous Barriers
Teaser: A new vaccine may be able to reduce the large disease burden from hepatitis C virus in the United States, as well as globally.

Headlines: US Not Making the Grade on Cervical Cancer Screening
Teaser: Millions of women fail to get a Pap test; 93% of cervical cancers could be prevented by screening and HPV vaccination, the CDC says.

Headlines: First Serogroup B Meningococcal Vaccine Approved by FDA
Teaser: The US Food and Drug Administration has approved Trumenba, the first vaccine against invasive meningococcal disease caused by Neisseria meningitides serogroup B, to be licensed in the United States.

Headlines: Platelet Activation Seen as Key to MI, Pneumonia Link
Teaser: Patients with community-acquired pneumonia showing MI soon after hospitalization had elevations in multiple platelet-activation markers. But were the MIs really due to thrombus-mediated ischemia?

Headlines: Gardasil Does Not Increase MS Risk
Teaser: A large Scandinavian study showed that the human papillomavirus vaccination is not associated with the development of multiple sclerosis or other demyelinating diseases.

Headlines: MMRV Vaccine Safe, With Rare Adverse Effects
Teaser: Several of the evaluated adverse outcomes occurred rarely to not at all after vaccination with either MMR + V or the newer MMRV.

Headlines: Ebola Fears in Pregnant Women Reducing Healthcare Use
Teaser: Ebola fears and misconceptions reduced health facility use by pregnant and lactating women in Kenema District, Sierra Leone, according to focus group discussions with women and health workers.

Headlines: Influenza Hospitalizing Twice as Many as Last Year
Teaser: Influenza seasons dominated by an A(H3N2) virus, such as the current one, are tougher than most. A less effective vaccine makes it even worse.

Headlines: Endgame for Polio Eradication
Teaser: The American Academy of Pediatrics has issued a clinical report on how eliminating serotype 2 poliovirus from oral vaccine will lead to eradication of the disease.

Headlines: Texts Help Parents Remember Second Influenza Shot
Teaser: Pairing texted reminders with educational content worked best, a study found.

Headlines: No Evidence for Most TV Medical Advice, Study Shows
Teaser: Patients should be skeptical about claims and recommendations made on mainstream television medical talk shows.

Headlines: Discovery of Bourbon Virus Raises Many Questions
Teaser: A virus linked to the death of a Kansas farmer looks to be another tick-borne pathogen that has emerged in the nation's Midwest. How prevalent it is remains unknown.

Headlines: High-Dose Vaccine May Improve Influenza Protection in Elderly
Teaser: Frail and elderly adults are especially vulnerable to influenza. They also have a weakened ability to mount an immune response to the traditional influenza vaccine.

Headlines: Go Beyond Infectious Disease of the Month, Says Report
Teaser: The nation fixates on the latest infectious disease, but lowers its guard against ongoing and more widespread threats such as influenza, according to an annual public health report card.

Headlines: Influenza Activity on the Rise Nationwide
Teaser: From September 28 to December 6, overall US influenza activity increased, with the current vaccine offering little protection against more than half of influenza A (H3N2) viruses.

Headlines: Jury Still Out on Potential Ebola Treatments, EMA Says
Teaser: The safety or efficacy of experimental Ebola treatments remain unclear, the European Medicines Agency says in their first interim report on the development of Ebola treatments.

Headlines: Premature Birth Linked With Flu Complications in Young Children
Teaser: Children younger than two years who were born prematurely are at increased risk of being hospitalized if they develop influenza, according to a new systematic review and meta-analysis.

Headlines: Ebola Vaccine Trial Halted Temporarily After Joint Pains
Teaser: A clinical trial of an Ebola vaccine developed by Merck and NewLink has been halted temporarily as a precautionary measure after four patients complained of joint pains, the University of Geneva Hospital said.

Headlines: Vaccination Protects Children Against Allergic Disease
Teaser: Routine childhood vaccination does not increase the risk for allergies later in life, and can protect against atopic disease even in children with a parental history of atopy, new research has shown.

Headlines: Just-Approved Gardasil 9 Packs More HPV/Cancer Protection
Teaser: The new vaccine covers nine types of human papillomavirus, five more than the original Gardasil.

Headlines: Gut Microbiome Can Train Immune System to Fight Malaria
Teaser: A specific component of the human gut microbiome can stimulate an antibody response that is highly protective against malaria transmission.

Headlines: Ebola Survivors Crucial to Containing the Epidemic
Teaser: Thousands of Ebola survivors with little to no risk of re-infection are critical to controlling the epidemic and training them has the potential to save thousands of lives and decrease the spread of the virus.

Headlines: This Year's Flu Strain Tougher on Kids Than Other Strains
Teaser: If past performance is any indication, the flu strain that is circulating this year will be hard on children.

Headlines: Chikungunya: 11 Locally Spread Cases Confirmed‏ in Florida
Teaser: Chikungunya virus infection has now spread locally in Florida, and Puerto Rico has widespread Chikungunya activity, according to a recent report from the CDC.

Headlines: California Warns Against Intentional Measles Exposures
Teaser: California health officials on Monday warned parents against intentionally exposing their children to measles, which could worsen an outbreak in the state.

Headlines: No Link Between HPV Vaccination, Unsafe Sexual Behavior
Teaser: Adolescent girls who were vaccinated against HPV were not more likely to engage in unsafe sexual behavior or acquire sexually transmitted diseases than their unvaccinated peers in a new study.

Headlines: Vaccine Uptake Among Adults Better, but Still Low
Teaser: In 2013, adult uptake for herpes zoster, Tdap, and HPV vaccines increased slightly, but others did not, according to a CDC report.

Headlines: Measles Outbreak Sparks Bid to Strengthen Calif. Vaccine Law
Teaser: State lawmakers in California introduced legislation Wednesday that would require children to be fully vaccinated before going to school.

Headlines: OurNotes Project to Explore Patient-Generated EHR Data
Teaser: A Commonwealth Fund grant enables pilot  sites to explore how to get patient updates, additions, and corrections into the EHR by allowing patient contributions.

Headlines: Pneumococcal Vaccine May Not Prevent Invasive Disease in Kids
Teaser: In children with comorbid conditions, invasive pneumococcal disease causes higher morbidity and mortality, and many cases are caused by serotypes not included in current conjugate vaccines.

Headlines: 2015 ACIP Adult Schedule Highlights Pneumococcal Vaccine
Teaser: The 13-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine is now recommended, in addition to the previously recommended 23-valent pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine, for adults aged 65 years and older.

Headlines: Influenza Sending Record Number of Seniors to the Hospital
Teaser: In another sign of a bad season, the rate of seniors hospitalized for flu is the highest since the CDC began tracking this a decade ago.

Headlines: Cluster of Acute Flaccid Myelitis Linked to Enterovirus D68
Teaser: Researchers in Colorado describe cases of pediatric neurologic deficits and neuroimaging abnormalities that may be associated with the emerging enterovirus D68.

Headlines: US Measles Outbreak Worrisome, CDC Official Says
Teaser: Federal health officials urge healthcare providers to 'think measles' and help prevent the disease from becoming endemic again.

Headlines: Consent for Biobank Donations High in US Survey
Teaser: Donors want the simple courtesy of knowing how their tissues are being used, says the author of 'The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks.'

Headlines: Scientists Ask if Ebola Immunizes as Well as Kills
Teaser: A recent sharp drop in new Ebola infections in West Africa is prompting scientists to wonder whether the virus may be silently immunizing some people at the same time as killing their neighbors.

Headlines: ACIP Issues 2015 Pediatric Vaccine Schedule
Teaser: Updated vaccine recommendations for children and adolescents  are now available on the American Academy of Pediatrics and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention websites.

Headlines: FDA OKs Second Serogroup B Meningococcal Vaccine
Teaser: Before its approval, the vaccine received an emergency trial run on two university campuses beset by meningitis.

Headlines: Pertussis Booster Vaccines May Not Fight Disease Resurgence
Teaser: If the pertussis vaccine is 'leaky,' then a pertussis booster schedule will not have an effect on the resurgence of whooping cough.

Headlines: Underimmunized, Unvaccinated Families Cluster Together
Teaser: Families with underimmunized or unvaccinated children tend to cluster together, a new study shows.

Headlines: Seasonal Influenza Vaccine Only 23% Effective This Year
Teaser: An early analysis of the 2014 to 2015 influenza season indicates that the current vaccine is only 23% effective against H3N2 viruses, which are the predominant circulating strains.

Headlines: Influenza Vaccine May Protect Against Guillain-Barre Syndrome
Teaser: Influenza is known to increase the risk for GBS. A new study has predicted that the seasonal influenza vaccine may reduce the risk.

Headlines: Rotavirus Vaccination Coverage Remains Inconsistent
Teaser: Health departments can use immunization information systems to find sources of infection in the community and identify providers who may benefit from education about the rotavirus vaccine.

Headlines: Pertussis Immunity Lasts Only Few Years After DTaP Immunization
Teaser: The average duration of protection against pertussis after diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis (DTaP) immunization is only about three years, according to a review and meta-analysis of a dozen studies.

Headlines: Chikungunya Vaccine Trial Shows Promise
Teaser: A live recombinant vaccine against chikungunya infection, produced by modifying the measles vaccine virus, was safe and induced a good immune response in healthy volunteers in a new study from Austria.

Headlines: US Ebola Response Fed Fear, Presidential Commission Says
Teaser: The report recommends improving global health relationships and presenting a united front based on science, not politics.

Headlines: Ebola Crisis Leaves West Africa Vulnerable to Measles
Teaser: Disruptions to vaccination programs could result in 100,000 more infections and up to 16,000 deaths in three countries if an outbreak occurred.

Headlines: New Guidance Aims to Reduce Risks From Animals in Hospitals
Teaser: Animals can be present in hospitals for a variety of reasons - pet therapy, service animals, animals in research, and personal pet visitation - and in new guidance, the Society for Healthcare Epidemiology of America (SHEA) is advising healthcare facilities to establish policies to reduce the risks associated with their presence.

Headlines: Changing Etiology of Bacteremia in Kids Poses New Challenges
Teaser: Serious bacterial infection in children in the ED is increasingly healthcare-associated and less susceptible to empirical therapy.

Headlines: Physician Safe After Ebola Needlestick, Experimental Vaccine
Teaser: Although there was no clear evidence of Ebola infection, the patient's response was consistent with a response to the experimental vaccine.

Headlines: FDA Advisers Recommend Overhaul of 2015 Flu Vaccine
Teaser: Surveillance data showed that new influenza strains are now circulating; past season's vaccine very ineffective.

Headlines: Hepatitis E Vaccine Effective and Long Lasting
Teaser: The hepatitis E vaccine was effective, and the protection it provided lasted for up to 4.5 years after vaccination, a long-term study showed.

Headlines: ED Docs Well Placed to Give Positive Info About Vaccination
Teaser: Emergency physicians are in a position to screen children for vaccinations and counter misconceptions about vaccine safety by delivering the facts in a nonjudgmental way.

Headlines: Childhood Vaccines: Parents Often Ask Docs to Spread Them Out
Teaser: Physicians need strategies to increase the timeliness and completeness of vaccinations.

Headlines: CDC Says Influenza Vaccine Only 18% Effective This Year
Teaser: The effectiveness was previously reported to be 23%. The CDC's Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices recommendations also did not include universal meningococcal B vaccination.

Headlines: Bavarian Nordic Vaccine Helps Prolong Life in Prostate Cancer Trial
Teaser: An experimental therapeutic vaccine from Danish drugmaker Bavarian Nordic helped significantly extend survival in patients with advanced prostate cancer, according to results of a small early-stage trial conducted by the U.S. National Cancer Institute.

Headlines: Herpes Zoster More Common Than Thought in Children
Teaser: A population-based study showed that herpes zoster incidence among only children who had varicella infection is higher than previously reported.

Headlines: Intranasal Flu Vaccine Appears Safe for Egg-Allergic Kids
Teaser: Children with a history of allergic reactions or anaphylaxis after egg exposure safely tolerated the live attenuated vaccine.

Headlines: New 9-vHPV Offers Additional Protection -- Problem Is Uptake
Teaser: The newly approved 9-valent vaccine against human papillomavirus (HPV) offers additional protection, but the problem is uptake of this vaccination.

Headlines: Alternative to HIV Vaccine Blocks Infection in Animal Models
Teaser: A genetically engineered fusion protein gave vaccine-like protection against an immunodeficiency virus in monkeys, despite repeated viral challenges.

Headlines: 'Be My Individual Mandate': A Twitter Valentine for Health Policy
Teaser: Healthcare professionals and policy wonks toast Valentine's Day with humor on Twitter using the special #healthpolicyvalentines hashtag.

Headlines: Next-Generation HIV and Hep C Treatment Plans Ahead at CROI
Teaser: Researchers spell out what's next for antiretroviral therapy after excitement about the Mississippi infant fades. Hepatitis C experts target genotype 3 as the next population needing therapies.

Headlines: AAP Updates Measles Recommendations
Teaser: In light of the ongoing measles outbreak, the American Academy of Pediatrics has updated its RedBook chapter.

Headlines: FDA Commissioner Says Measles Outbreak 'Alarming'
Teaser: Describing the latest measles outbreak as 'alarming,' Dr. Margaret Hamburg, outgoing commissioner of the U.S. Food and Drug Administration, said on Tuesday that the measles vaccine 'should be used by everyone who has not been vaccinated.'

Headlines: Serogroup B Meningitis Vaccine Protective in College Outbreak
Teaser: The serogroup B meningococcal vaccine 4CMenB (Bexsero) protected vaccinated students from infection, but not from becoming carriers.

Headlines: MMR Vaccine Not Linked to Autism, Even in High-Risk Kids
Teaser: Receipt of the MMR vaccine was not linked to an increased risk for autism spectrum disorder, even when older siblings had the disorder, a new study has shown.

Headlines: Glaxo Recalls Flu Vaccine Due to Potency Issue
Teaser: GlaxoSmithKline is recalling the FluLaval Quadrivalent Thimerosal-Free vaccine because it may offer suboptimal protection against some influenza strains.

Headlines: Perinatal HBV: Timely Immunoprophylaxis Effective
Teaser: Maternal antiviral therapy may be the next step for further decreasing perinatal HBV infections.

Headlines: Measles: Travel, Lack of Vaccination Root of US Outbreaks
Teaser: Nearly all the 159 measles cases reported in the United States in the first 3 months of 2015 have been linked to virus imported from US travelers and foreign visitors.

Headlines: More Intussusception Hospitalizations in California After Rotavirus Vaccine Intro
Teaser: The risk of intussusception hospitalizations in infants in California has risen since the introduction of rotavirus vaccines in 2006 and 2008, according to researchers.

Headlines: Military Dependents Less Likely to Be Current on Vaccinations
Teaser: Children of active-duty military members were more likely to be incompletely vaccinated compared with other US children, according to results of a new study.

Headlines: Vaccinating Boys Against HPV Could Prevent OPC
Teaser: Vaccinating adolescent boys against the human papillomavirus (HPV) might be a cost-effective way of preventing oropharyngeal cancer (OPC), a statistical model has demonstrated.

Headlines: Routine Rotavirus Vaccination Reduced US Disease Activity
Teaser: The CDC has reported a sustained decrease in laboratory detection of rotavirus after implementation of routine vaccination in the United States in 2006.

Headlines: California Bill Banning Child Vaccine Exemptions Moves Ahead
Teaser: California lawmakers on Wednesday pushed forward a bill that would ban parents from citing their personal beliefs as a reason to let their school-going children remain unvaccinated.

Headlines: Ritual, Not Science, Keeps the Annual Physical Alive
Teaser: There's little evidence that annual physicals actually do any good for healthy adults.

Headlines: Ebola Vaccine Safe, Immunogenic in Phase I Trials
Teaser: A genetically engineered Ebola vaccine was safe and induced a significant immune response in multiple phase 1 trials, researchers reported.

Headlines: Douglas Lowy, MD, Assumes Helm at National Cancer Institute
Teaser: One of Dr Lowy's first tasks will be to testify before the Senate Appropriations Committee on April 30 about the budget needs of his agency and the NIH.

Headlines: Gardasil HPV 9 Vaccine Launched in Canada
Teaser: The new 9-valent version of the human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine is now available in Canada. It is already available in the United States, and is close to approval in Europe.

Headlines: Probiotic Nose Drops May Protect Against Meningitis
Teaser: Nose drops containing harmless Neisseria lactamica reduced the likelihood of students being colonized with the related bacteria that cause meningitis.

Headlines: ACIP Updates Recommendations, Adds 9-Valent HPV Vaccine
Teaser: The Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices has recommended the 9-valent human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine as one of three HPV vaccines that can be used for routine vaccination.

Headlines: White House Releases Action Plan on Antibiotic Resistance
Teaser: The call to action sets 5-year goals to help ensure appropriate use and encourage development of new diagnostics and therapies.

Headlines: ACIP Updates Typhoid Vaccination Recommendations
Teaser: The typhoid vaccine should not be given routinely in the United States but should be given to patients traveling to certain countries, as specified in the updated ACIP recommendations.

Headlines: FDA Panel to Discuss Ebola Vaccine Development in May
Teaser: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration said an advisory panel will discuss the development of Ebola vaccines, days after an American health worker was flown back after being tested positive for Ebola in Sierra Leone.

Headlines: Pockets of Low Immunization Contributed to Measles Outbreak
Teaser: Because measles is highly contagious, vaccination rates between 96% and 99% are required to maintain herd immunity; local vaccination monitoring may be warranted, expert suggests.

Headlines: Tdap Vaccination During Pregnancy Remains Low
Teaser: Just more than half of women reported Tdap vaccination before, during, or after pregnancy, which falls far short of current recommendations for vaccination during pregnancy.

Headlines: Celiac Disease Lowers Hepatitis B Vaccine Response
Teaser: In children with celiac disease, immunologic response to the hepatitis B vaccine is impaired, even after a gluten-free diet or a booster, new research shows.

Headlines: Pneumonia Vaccine Benefits Extend to Unvaccinated Children
Teaser: Rates of community-acquired pneumonia declined in unvaccinated children after the introduction of the PCV10 pneumococcal vaccine, report researchers.

Headlines: Meningitis Cases Triple in Two Weeks in Niger, More Than 400 Dead
Teaser: An outbreak of meningitis with "unprecedented features" is spreading rapidly in Niger, with a tripling of cases in the past two weeks, hundreds of deaths so far this year and vaccines in short supply, the World Health Organization said on Friday.

Headlines: California Senate Votes to End Beliefs Waiver for School Vaccinations
Teaser: California parents who do not vaccinate their children would have to home-school them under a bill passed Thursday in California.

Headlines: FDA Panel Considers Best Approval Process for Ebola Vaccines
Teaser: The Vaccines and Related Biological Products Advisory Committee to the FDA met to discuss licensure of Ebola virus disease vaccines and possible ways to demonstrate their effectiveness.

Headlines: IBD Patients May Need More Vaccination Counseling
Teaser: Patients with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) who lack sufficient knowledge and uptake of vaccines might benefit from more counseling from gastroenterologists and primary care providers, new research from Canada suggests.

Headlines: Global Pertussis Initiative Stresses Vaccination in Pregnancy
Teaser: Pregnant women should be vaccinated against pertussis during each pregnancy to protect their infants from the infection, according to new recommendations from the Global Pertussis Initiative.

Headlines: HPV: 1.1 Million More Women Started Vaccine After ACA Passed
Teaser: The Affordable Care Act, which extended health coverage and erased copayments for preventive treatments, was associated with 1.1 million more young women initiating the human papillomavirus vaccine.

Headlines: At Least 265 Dead in Niger Meningitis Epidemic
Teaser: At least 265 people have died so far this year in a meningitis epidemic in Niger amid a shortage of vaccines needed to prevent the disease's spread, the West African nation's health minister said on Tuesday.

Headlines: How to Treat Side Effects of New Cancer Immunotherapies
Teaser: A new review article details the major side effects of immunotherapies for cancer and provides advice on how to treat them.

Headlines: Timely Pertussis Vaccination Could Save Infant Lives
Teaser: Timely infant and maternal pertussis vaccination could reduce infant mortality from the disease, according to the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).

Headlines: Primary Care at Apex of Deliberations Over Vaccines
Teaser: Physicians are the guardians of public health, but recent measles outbreaks have shown that renewed vigilance is needed.

Headlines: Waning Immunity to Tdap Vaccine in Adolescents
Teaser: A study in Washington State has found that immunity to the acellular Tdap pertussis vaccine is 73% at year 1 but declines to 34% at years 2 to 4 among adolescents.

Headlines: High Cure Rates Will Not Curb Hepatitis C, Expert Warns
Teaser: New drug combinations are impressing with cure rates nearing 100%, but with up to 170 million infected around the world, it can't be wiped out, say skeptics.

Headlines: Pivotal Vaccine Trial to Inoculate Elderly from Pneumonia
Teaser: The PCV13 vaccine is effective in preventing community-acquired pneumonia in an older population, according to one of the largest vaccine trials in history.

Headlines: HPV Vaccine Uptake Slowing in Youngest Girls
Teaser: Many physicians don't strongly recommend the HPV vaccine to the youngest eligible girls, and parental objections to the vaccine appear to be on the rise, survey results show.

Headlines: Newer Herpes Zoster Vaccine Effective Even in Older Adults
Teaser: A recombinant subunit vaccine significantly lowered the risk for herpes zoster in adults aged 50 years or older, with comparable efficacy in adults aged 70 years or older.

Headlines: Benefits of Early HPV Vaccination Emerge Rapidly
Teaser: Reductions in cervical dysplasia and apparent reductions in anogenital warts were seen in 14- to 17-year-olds after vaccination at 12 to 13 years of age.

Headlines: Rapid Tests Needed Quickly to Improve Ebola Screening
Teaser: The need for an alternative to automatic isolation for patients with suspected Ebola is urgent, especially in light of the changing symptoms of the disease.

Headlines: California Governor Signs Bill Limiting School Vaccine Exemptions
Teaser: California Governor Jerry Brown on Tuesday signed a bill eliminating the state's personal beliefs exemption for school vaccine requirements - legislation that was prompted by a measles outbreak at Disneyland linked to low vaccination rates.

Headlines: ACOG Updates Recommendations to Include 9-Valent HPV Vaccine
Teaser: Only half of teenaged girls have received one dose of the HPV vaccine, but coverage of 80% would reduce cervical cancer burden by 53,000 cases.

Headlines: Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever Hits Some American Indians Hard
Teaser: Rocky Mountain spotted fever has severely affected Arizona American Indian communities, with millions of dollars lost because of decreased productivity from long-term disability and premature death.

Headlines: Tracking System Increases Hepatitis Vaccination Rates
Teaser: Rates of hepatitis A and hepatitis B vaccination improved significantly in patients on a liver transplant list after a nurse-led intervention was implemented.

Headlines: WHO Updates Vaccine-Derived Poliovirus Data
Teaser: The WHO's plan to eliminate serotype 2 from poliovirus vaccine and return to inactivated vaccine was still on track after updated surveillance statistics were considered.

Headlines: S Korea Conducts Experimental Plasma Therapy on MERS Patients
Teaser: Two South Korean hospitals are conducting experimental treatment on Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) patients, injecting them with blood plasma from recovering patients, the health ministry said on Tuesday, as four new cases were reported.

Headlines: Worst of MERS Outbreak May Be Over in South Korea
Teaser: The MERS outbreak that has spread through health facilities in South Korea may have peaked, although two hospitals that treated people with the deadly respiratory disease have been sealed off, officials said.

Headlines: Shingles Vaccination Helps Some Who Later Develop the Virus
Teaser: Adults who developed herpes zoster despite having received the herpes zoster vaccine had a reduced risk for painful complications compared with their unvaccinated counterparts.

Headlines: Single Dose of HPV-16/18 Vaccine Looks to Be Sufficient
Teaser: A new analysis suggests that a single dose of the HPV-16/18 vaccine (Cervarix) may be as effective as the standard three-dose regimen.

Headlines: Rotavirus Vaccine Linked to Fewer Hospitalizations for Kids
Teaser: The rate of hospitalizations for acute gastroenteritis dropped by more than half after implementation of routine rotavirus vaccination.

Headlines: Nonmedical Exemptions for Vaccines Endanger Public, AMA Says
Teaser: American Medical Association delegates voted to support legislation that removes the option to refuse immunizations for philosophic or religious reasons.

Headlines: FDA Approves Mid-Stage Trial of Vaccine to Reverse Type 1 Diabetes
Teaser: Diabetes researchers are hoping that the almost century-old bacillus Calmette-Guerin (BCG) vaccine for preventing tuberculosis may also reverse type 1 diabetes.

Headlines: Technology Scans Lifetime Viral History With Blood Drop
Teaser: The test, which costs about the same as current tests for a single virus, may help establish patterns between diseases and the full array of viruses a person may have encountered.

Headlines: RA: Dendritic Cell Vaccine Suppressed Immune Dysfunction
Teaser: Autologous dendritic cells conditioned by exposure to citrullinated peptides were able to correct some rheumatoid arthritis-related immune problems in patients with high-risk HLA-DRB1 alleles.

Headlines: Ebola Drug Development Slowed by Lack of Patients
Teaser: Ebola drug development is facing hurdles, but vaccine trials are moving at unprecedented rates, with trials that usually take years to implement getting under way within weeks.

Headlines: Pneumonia With Cardiac Event in Hospital Predicts Poor Outcome
Teaser: Patients hospitalized with community-acquired pneumonia who have a heart attack or atrial fibrillation are more likely to die or have another cardiac event     within 2 years, according to a new study.

Headlines: Niger Meningitis Epidemic Has Peaked, 545 Dead - WHO Says
Teaser: An epidemic of meningitis has killed 545 people in Niger, out of 8,234 people who caught the disease, but has now peaked, the World Health Organization said on Tuesday.

Headlines: Some Bird Flu Viruses in US Potential Threat to Humans: CDC
Teaser: Birds infected with highly pathogenic avian influenza A H5 viruses in the United States could cause human infection, the CDC says in a new advisory.

Headlines: MERS Infects 10 in South Korea But No Virus Mutation - WHO
Teaser: Ten people in South Korea are confirmed as having the Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) virus, transmitted by a traveller, but there has been no sustained human-to-human spread, the World Health Organization (WHO) said on Friday.

Headlines: Measles Outbreaks Include Unvaccinated Healthcare Workers
Teaser: Officials are calling for mandatory MMR vaccination after a series of measles outbreaks in Europe that involved unvaccinated healthcare workers.

Headlines: Images, Stories of Disease Can Change Attitudes About Vaccines
Teaser: Pictures and stories about children who suffered from measles, mumps, and rubella swayed survey participants' feelings about vaccines more than correcting myths about vaccines and autism.

Headlines: ACIP Updates Influenza Vaccine Recommendations
Teaser: All persons at least 6 months of age should have routine annual influenza vaccination unless they have contraindications, according to the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices.

Headlines: Vaccine-Related Seizures Don't Affect Outcome in Dravet Syndrome
Teaser: Study results showing that seizures linked to vaccinations, a well-known risk in Dravet syndrome patients, don't affect cognitive outcome or disease course might be a relief to physicians and parents.

Headlines: Physicians Blamed for Low HPV Vaccination Rates
Teaser: Insufficient recommendations by clinicians is the 'primary roadblock' to improving vaccination against HPV, the director of the CDC's National Center for Immunization and Respiratory Diseases said.

Headlines: Dengue Vaccine Candidate Shows Uneven Efficacy
Teaser: A new dengue vaccine candidate lowers the risk for dengue infection, but the vaccine's role among younger patients is still unclear.

Headlines: Drug Stops Marburg Virus in Monkeys, Appears Safe in Humans
Teaser: AVI-7288, directed against viral messenger RNA and meant for postexposure prevention of Marburg hemorrhagic fever, was effective in monkeys infected with MARV-Musoke and was safe in human volunteers.

Headlines: First Malaria Vaccine Approved by EU Regulators
Teaser: Mosquirix, which offers modest protection against the deadly disease, now awaits review by the World Health Organization.

Headlines: CDC: Hispanics More Likely to Believe Antibiotics Lessen Colds
Teaser: US Hispanics are almost twice as likely as all patients to believe that taking antibiotics reduces cold symptoms, and nearly three times as likely to obtain antibiotics not prescribed by a clinician.

Headlines: Adjuvants Could Boost Value of Influenza Vaccine in Pandemic
Teaser: Although the US national prepandemic influenza vaccine stockpile contains two adjuvants, one appears to be more effective than the other.

Headlines: Drug-Resistant Microbes Appear More Fit, Virulent
Teaser: If the resistant microbes do have a competitive advantage over nonresistant microbes, then antibiotic resistance may be an even bigger problem than previously believed.

Headlines: CDC Yellow Book: 2016 Edition Now Available
Teaser: The newest edition of the CDC Health Information for International Travel is now available, with updated information on global diseases, vaccination recommendations, and tips for healthy travel.

Headlines: New Oral Vaccine Protects Children From Helicobacter Pylori Infection
Teaser: A new oral recombinant vaccine protects children against infection with Helicobacter pylori, researchers from China report.

Headlines: Early Treatment Trial to Headline AIDS Conference
Teaser: Results from the START trial, stopped early because data showed that people with HIV have a much lower risk for AIDS if they start treatment early, will be presented, along with other pivotal work.

Headlines: Burden of CAP Requiring Hospitalization High for US Adults
Teaser: The burden of community-acquired pneumonia requiring hospitalization among US adults is substantial and markedly higher with increasing age, even though no single pathogen tends to prevail.

Headlines: Safety Profile of HPV Vaccines Under Review in Europe
Teaser: The European Medicines Agency is reviewing the safety profile of human papilloma virus vaccines but says there should be no change in their use at this time.

Headlines: Oral Cholera Vaccine Safe, Effective in First Real-life Trial
Teaser: An oral cholera vaccine safely protected poor urban populations from endemic cholera and could facilitate global control efforts, according to results from the first real-life, cluster-randomized open-label trial.

Headlines: HIV Vaccine Researcher Gets 57 Months in Prison for Fraud
Teaser: Dong Pyou Han spiked rabbit sera with human antibodies to fake an immune response to an experimental HIV vaccine. Prosecutors said a prison sentence would send a warning to other scientists.

Headlines: As Cuba-US Relations Thaw, Potential Medical Advances Grow
Teaser: Cubans gain access to resources and recognition of innovations; the US can learn from innovations in wound care, family medicine, and immunology and about healthcare that excels with minimal spending.

Headlines: Attorneys Seek to Challenge California's New School Vaccination Law
Teaser: Opponents of California's new law tightening school vaccination rules said on Wednesday they had put together a team of attorneys to challenge the measure, which was prompted by a measles outbreak at Disneyland that sickened more than 100 people.

Headlines: Hepatitis B Vaccine Ineffective in Most Patients With RA
Teaser: Many patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) do not achieve adequate levels of protection against hepatitis B when vaccinated with HBVAXPRO-10.

Headlines: Flu Vaccine Long Lasting, Study Suggests
Teaser: The influenza vaccine can protect for 6 months and last throughout the flu season, which is longer than previous studies have shown.

Headlines: Infants More Likely to Contract Pertussis From Siblings
Teaser: After 2008, siblings replaced mothers as the main source of infection, possibly because of waning immunity after childhood vaccination.

Headlines: West Nile Virus Rising in California, CDC Reports
Teaser: A new report from the CDC summarized 2014 surveillance data for nationally notifiable arboviral diseases in the United States.

Headlines: Routine Shingles Vaccination in 50-Year-Olds Does Not Pay
Teaser: A new study supported the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices recommendation that routine immunization against herpes zoster in immunocompetent adults should begin at age 60 years.

Headlines: AAP Backs Mandatory Vaccination for HCPs
Teaser: Influenza vaccination should be mandatory for all healthcare personnel, according to the AAP; the AAP also made recommendations for pediatric influenza vaccination for the 2015-2016 season.

Headlines: ACIP Changes Pneumococcal Vaccine Interval in Low-Risk Elderly
Teaser: Guidelines recommend 1 year between two pneumococcal vaccines in healthy older adults.

Headlines: Japan Scheme for Managing Symptoms After HPV Vaccine
Teaser: Japanese authorities have issued a guideline and designated health centers for managing symptoms, including chronic pain, after HPV vaccination.

Headlines: No Safety Concerns With Inactivated Poliovirus Vaccine: Report
Teaser: Data from the U.S. Vaccine Adverse Event Reporting System (VAERS) provide reassurance on the safety of inactivated poliovirus vaccine (IPV).

Headlines: U.S. Vaccination Rates High, But Pockets of Unvaccinated Pose Risk
Teaser: The vast majority of U.S. kindergarten-age children are vaccinated against preventable diseases but sizable pockets of unprotected children still exist, posing a public health threat, according to a government study.

Headlines: Annual Influenza Vaccinations Help the Elderly
Teaser: When the seasonal influenza vaccine is a relatively good match with the circulating virus, vaccination is associated with lower morbidity and mortality in elderly adults.

Headlines: Tdap Booster Rates Triple With Autoreminders to Clinics
Teaser: Alerts resulted in 76% of adult patients being up-to-date in immunizations, as opposed to 59% in clinics without the alerts.

Headlines: Group Offers Guidelines to Lessen Vaccination Pain
Teaser: Clinicians can shuffle the order of vaccine injections, leverage the calming influence of parents and breast-feeding, and routinely apply topical anesthetic to ease vaccination pain for patients.

Headlines: Vaccine Exemption Levels Low in US, Coverage Levels High
Teaser: "Gratifying" new data show that the vast majority of parents continue to protect their children with recommended vaccinations, the CDC reports.

Headlines: Antivirals May Work Against Ebola
Teaser: Four people with real or potential Ebola exposure gained through needlesticks were treated with Favipiravir and did not develop the disease.

Headlines: Cholera Vaccine: Reduction to Single Dose May Save Lives
Teaser: A single dose of oral cholera vaccine may be as or more effective than the approved two doses of the vaccine in situations in which supplies are limited.

Headlines: Rhode Island Move to Mandate HPV Vaccine in Schools Faces Criticism
Teaser: When Rhode Island seventh graders start school next month, the state's Department of Health will require they be vaccinated against the sexually transmitted human papillomavirus, over the protests of parent groups.

Headlines: Project Boosts Vaccination Rates in At-Risk Pediatric Patients
Teaser: A quality improvement project directed primarily at providers significantly improved PCV13 and PPSV23 vaccination rates in high-risk pediatric rheumatology patients.

Headlines: HIV-Positive Youth May Lack Immunity to MMR Diseases
Teaser: Despite vaccination, one third to one half of children who contracted HIV at birth did not show immunity to measles, mumps, or rubella (MMR) in a retrospective study.

Headlines: Clinicians See Increase in Vaccine Acceptance
Teaser: In the wake of the West Coast measles outbreak last year, clinicians tell Medscape how parents have changed their views on vaccines.

Headlines: Chickenpox Decline Continues, Even in Unvaccinated Groups
Teaser: Varicella has continued to decline in the United States as vaccination coverage with the two-dose program has increased, in part because of herd immunity protecting those who were not vaccinated.

Headlines: Would Eliminating the Annual Physical Dismantle Primary Care?
Teaser: Experts argued for and against the annual physical and provided recommendations for improvement in opinion pieces published in the New England Journal of Medicine.

Headlines: Concomitant Tdap, Influenza Vaccines Safe in Pregnancy
Teaser: The risk for adverse acute events or adverse birth outcomes was no higher for coadministered Tdap and influenza vaccines compared with sequentially administered vaccines, according to a 6-year study.

Headlines: Effective HAART Reduces HBV Risk in Men With HIV
Teaser: Treatment that brought HIV viral loads to undetectable levels also prevented additional susceptibility to HBV, but HBV vaccination is still needed.

Headlines: Traveling Americans at Risk for Hepatitis A, Measles
Teaser: Fewer than half of people who had a CDC pretravel healthcare visit got the MMR vaccine before their trip, study says. A 2nd study reports a hepatitis outbreak among unvaccinated Americans in Mexico.

Headlines: Large Number of Children in US at Risk for Measles
Teaser: Numbers from the National Immunization Survey show that even a small sustained drop in vaccinations from current levels could open up the risk for a widespread outbreak.

Headlines: Test Hepatitis B Vaccine Response Earlier in Infants, CDC Says
Teaser: The interval to assess infants' responses to the hepatitis B vaccine series has been shortened to between 9 and 12 months in a new CDC updated report.

Headlines: Reader Poll: Have You Received a Flu Vaccine This Season?
Teaser: Vaccinating more than half of healthcare workers against influenza in a given setting may help to only a limited extent.

Headlines: OK for Flu Shot With Nivolumab, Other Checkpoint Inhibitors?
Teaser: Is it safe and effective to give a flu shot to cancer patients on new immunotherapies?

Headlines: Flu Vaccine May Cut Pneumonia Hospitalization Risk in Half
Teaser: A higher proportion of patients with community-acquired pneumonia had received the influenza vaccine compared with patients hospitalized for pneumonia with laboratory-confirmed influenza.

Headlines: Most US Adults Support Mandatory Mental Health Coverage
Teaser: A majority of US adults support mandated mental health coverage in health plans.

Headlines: Texting Reminders Increased Teen Vaccination Rates 30%
Teaser: Bidirectional text messages to parents increased rates of adolescent vaccinations and use of needed services.

Headlines: Arrowhead's Hep B Data Shows Promise, Shares Jump
Teaser: Arrowhead Research Corp is one step closer to achieving a cure for hepatitis B infection, Chief Executive Christopher Anzalone said.

Headlines: Recent Pertussis Uptick May Come From a Different Species
Teaser: The current pertussis vaccine might not protect against Bordetella parapertussis.

Headlines: Benefit of Healthcare Worker Flu Shots Questioned
Teaser: At one institution, the rate of hospital-acquired influenza plateaued once about half the healthcare personnel were vaccinated.

Headlines: No Link Seen Between Bivalent HPV Vaccine and Early Miscarriage
Teaser: Women who conceive within 90 days of vaccination with the bivalent human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine do not have an increased risk of miscarriage, according to long-term follow-up of participants in a randomized trial in Costa Rica.

Headlines: Case Reports of 'Syndrome' Appearing After HPV Vaccination
Teaser: Clinicians are reporting a syndrome of pain, fatigue, and autonomic dysfunction appearing after human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccination.

Headlines: Flu Vaccine a Closer Match, Time to Get Vaccinated, CDC Says
Teaser: Some good news from last year though; data for the 2014-2015 flu season shows similar vaccination rates for healthcare professionals as in the previous year, but still up from past years.

Headlines: FDA Advisers Urge Approval of New Flu Vaccine for Seniors
Teaser: The panel requested more data on safety with repeated vaccination with Fluad.

Headlines: Adjuvant Treatment, Peptide Vaccine Do Not Improve Melanoma Survival
Teaser: Adjuvant treatment with granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor (GM-CSF) and peptide vaccine does not improve survival in patients with high-risk melanoma, researchers report.

Headlines: Study Dispels Claim That Childhood Vaccinations Cause Retinal Bleeding
Teaser: A recent vaccination is often used as a defense in child abuse cases, particularly when evidence of retinal hemorrhage is presented. However, a new study shows no temporal link between vaccinations and retinal hemorrhage.

Headlines: Human Tularemia Cases Rising in Some States, CDC Reports
Teaser: The CDC reported a dramatic increase in human tularemia cases from January to September 2015 in Colorado, Nebraska, South Dakota, and Wyoming.

Headlines: On-Demand Preexposure Prophylaxis Effective Against HIV
Teaser: IPERGAY results also found risk for gastrointestinal and renal adverse events. We now have better tools for preventing and treating, but the challenge is working them into practice, experts commented.

Headlines: Anthrax Vaccine Approved for Postexposure Protection
Teaser: Studies indicate that people receiving BioThrax after a confirmed or suspected exposure to the bacterium that causes the disease may have a 70% chance of surviving.

Headlines: RSV: Investigational Drug Shows Promise in Challenge Study
Teaser: ALS-008176 reduced viral load, hastened viral clearance, and reduced clinical disease severity in healthy adults inoculated with RSV in a randomized controlled trial.

Headlines: Europe Again Says HPV Vax Safe,  but Petition in Spain
Teaser: Europe has again said that HPV vaccination is safe and that it is not causally linked to chronic syndromes, but some doctors remain unconvinced.

Headlines: CDC Wants MSM Status Added to Meningococcal Case Reports
Teaser: From 2012 to 2015, 527 cases were documented among men aged 18 to 64 years in this population.

Headlines: FDA Developing Pathway Toward Maternal Immunization
Teaser: At a hearing, the FDA's vaccine advisory panel discussed steps that will be needed for vaccines to be licensed for use in pregnant women specifically to prevent disease in their infants.

Headlines: Chronic Symptoms After HPV Vaccination: Danes Start Study
Teaser: Danish specialists are investigating more than 1300 girls with chronic symptoms after HPV vaccination.

Headlines: Retail Health Clinics to Continue to Boom as Profits Soar
Teaser: Expected to be able to handle 25 million patient visits by 2017, many physicians are wary of the potential of these clinics to affect business and patient outcomes.

Headlines: RSV Vaccine Data Promising for Common Pediatric Infection
Teaser: If the results hold in future trials, a needle-free vaccine could be 'less than a decade away.'

Headlines: Europe Concludes Syndromes Are Not Caused by HPV Vaccine
Teaser: The European Medicines Agency has concluded its safety review of the HPV vaccines, and says the evidence does not support causation of syndromes.

Headlines: Many Pediatricians Dismiss Parents Who Veto Infant Vaccines
Teaser: The complex dynamics of vaccine refusal need further study.

Headlines: Legionellosis Incidence Increases; Better Diagnostics Needed
Teaser: The CDC reports that during 2011 to 2013, nearly half of patients with legionellosis required intensive care, and nearly 1 in 10 died, with higher disease incidence seen among blacks than whites.

Headlines: TB Now Ranks With AIDS  as a Leading Cause of Death Worldwide
Teaser: The worldwide TB rate has dropped by half since 1990, but the world still needs to ramp up its efforts to halt deaths from the curable disease, according to a new WHO report.

Headlines: Many Countries Deny Antiretrovirals to Undocumented Migrants
Teaser: In Europe, not all immigrants infected with HIV receive therapy, or even get tested, new research indicates.

Headlines: Physicians' Communication Style Likely Lowers HPV Vaccinations
Teaser: Many physicians are not recommending HPV vaccination of children consistently or effectively, according to a new study.

Headlines: HPV Vaccination Rates Low Among Adolescent Males
Teaser: Human papilloma virus vaccination rates in adolescent males have increased in recent years, but remain very low, a new study has showed.

Headlines: ACIP Supports Meningitis B Vaccine for Teens, Young Adults
Teaser: Vaccination at ages 16 to 23 years may help protection last into the highest-risk period.

Headlines: Tdap Safe in Pregnancy After Other Recent Tetanus Vaccine
Teaser: Pregnant women given Tdap had no increase in acute adverse events or adverse birth outcomes associated with relatively recent receipt of a prior tetanus-containing vaccination.

Headlines: MSSA Mortality Similar to MRSA in Infants
Teaser: Hospital infection control practices should broaden to include all S aureus infections, not just those that are methicillin resistant.

Headlines: Routine Adolescent Tdap Vaccination Not Good Enough
Teaser: Tdap vaccination of adolescents provides moderate protection the first year and very little protection after that.

Headlines: New Vaccines in 2016 Pediatric Immunization Schedule
Teaser: Recommendations for the recently licensed meningococcal B and 9-valent human papillomavirus vaccine are now in the official 2016 childhood immunization schedule

Headlines: 2016 Adult Immunization Schedule Includes New Vaccines
Teaser: New vaccines against meningococcal serogroup B and human papillomavirus and a revision to the pneumococcal vaccine recommendation are among the 2016 changes.

Headlines: CDC Alert: Severe Influenza Illness Reported
Teaser: Clinicians should initiate antiviral treatment to very ill and high-risk patients suspected of having influenza without waiting for test results. ICU admissions and deaths have been reported.

Headlines: Mixed Rotavirus Vaccine Series Safe and Immunogenic
Teaser: Rotavirus vaccination series using either a single vaccine or a combination of the approved vaccines was equally safe and immunogenic.

Headlines: CDC Expects 'Limited Outbreaks' of Zika Infections in US
Teaser: On a day when both the CDC and the WHO addressed the rising threat of the Zika virus, one WHO official warned that the virus is "spreading explosively" in the Americas.

Headlines: Hepatitis B Vaccine Booster Unnecessary
Teaser: A hepatitis B vaccine booster is unnecessary, according to a 30-year study of antibody response.

Headlines: Top US Cancer Centers Call for Greater Uptake of HPV Vaccine
Teaser: NCI-designated cancer centers in the United States have issued a call to action to improve uptake of the human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine across the country in both males and females.

Headlines: HPV16 in the Mouth Linked to Increased Risk for HNSCC
Teaser: The detection of human papillomavirus (HPV) type 16 in the mouth was associated with a 22-fold increased risk for oropharyngeal cancer in a new study.

Headlines: Molecular Signatures Explain Unique Responses to Vaccination
Teaser: Patients who describe influenza-like symptoms after vaccination have a distinct genetic signature compared with patients who do not have such a reaction.

Headlines: Updated Guideline on Cervical Cancer Screening Issued by ACOG
Teaser: An FDA-approved HPV test can be considered an alternative to cytology testing in women aged 25 years and older; screening should start at age 21 years.

Headlines: Infectious Disease News in 2015: How Much Do You Remember?
Teaser: There was a lot happening in the field of infectious diseases this year, from the increasing threat of antibiotic resistance, to the expansion of diseases that used to be rare in the United States, to a major study that changed the way HIV will be treated. Take the following quiz to see how well you followed the news this year.

Headlines: CDC Warns About Syringe Reuse in Workplace Influenza Shots
Teaser: Multiple safety failures led to the need for HIV, hepatitis B, and hepatitis C testing plus readministration of influenza vaccinations for 67 employees who received questionable vaccinations at work.

Headlines: EU Regulators Approve Sixfold Childhood Vaccine (Vaxelis)
Teaser: The new vaccine protects against six different disorders (diphtheria, tetanus, pertussis, hepatitis B, poliomyelitis, and invasive diseases caused by HiB) in a single shot.

Headlines: Viral Infections Leave Telltale Gene Expression Signature
Teaser: The transcriptional signature after influenza vaccination is the same as the transcriptional signature after natural infection with influenza.

Headlines: US Complacent on Infectious Disease Threats, Report Shows
Teaser: The United States needs to do more to boost its ability to prevent and control infectious disease outbreaks, according to a report released today.

Headlines: Shingles Increases Risk for Stroke and Myocardial Infarction
Teaser: Two studies found an association between shingles and stroke, but only the one using self-controls over time identified an increased risk for heart attack.

Headlines: Quiz: Top Clinical News Stories of 2015
Teaser: The year has been filled with interesting, unexpected, and practice-changing news all around medicine. Test your knowledge on some of our most popular news stories of 2015 with this short quiz.

Headlines: Weighing Benefits of Therapies Against Cancer Risks in IBD
Teaser: Some biologic and immunomodulator therapies for IBD can increase cancer risks, evidence suggests. Experts put the findings in perspective and advised counseling patients about risks and benefits.

Headlines: Live Attenuated Vaccine Safe for Children With Egg Allergy
Teaser: A new study has found that live attenuated influenza vaccine is unlikely to trigger systemic anaphylaxis in children with egg allergy and well-controlled asthma.

Headlines: Study Suggests Bringing Back Whole-Cell Pertussis Vaccine
Teaser: Using a mixed vaccine series with whole-cell and Tdap could reduce pertussis incidence dramatically. But would parents accept the old vaccine with its associated adverse effects?

Headlines: Vaccine Refusal Puts Unvaccinated and Vaccinated at Risk
Teaser: A recent literature review has revealed that many of the individuals who contracted measles and pertussis in recent outbreaks were either unvaccinated or undervaccinated.

Headlines: Improved Varicella Vaccine Effectiveness With 2-Dose Regimen
Teaser: A two-dose varicella vaccine regimen is more effective than a one-dose regimen in preventing community transmission, researchers report.

Headlines: Low-Dose Steroids Generally Safe in Rheumatic Diseases
Teaser: A EULAR task force has concluded that long-term use of glucocorticoid doses of 5 mg/day or less is generally safe in treating rheumatic diseases.

Headlines: Discord Among Scientists Still Fuels Hazardous Research Debate
Teaser: The scientific communities still need to reach a consensus on issues related to gain-of-function research, and policy makers need to observe principles of international justice.

Headlines: Retail Clinic Usage Costs $14 More per Person per Year
Teaser: Almost 60% of retail visits were new uses, not substitutions for physician's office consultations or emergency department care, a new study has found.

Headlines: Investigational Therapeutic Genital Herpes Vaccine Promising
Teaser: Phase 2 data for a novel immunotherapy for genital herpes showed a significant reduction in viral shedding and lesions, although the reduction in lesions was also seen with placebo.

Headlines: FDA Advisers Pick 2016-2017 Influenza Vaccine Strains
Teaser: The panel recommended different A and B strains. As for this year, CDC says activity is low so far.

Headlines: Preventive Healthcare Best in Massachusetts, Worst in Mississippi
Teaser: New England states perform best overall in terms of access to healthcare and chronic disease prevention, according to latest America's Health Rankings report.

Headlines: HPV Throat Cancer in Men Increasing -- Link to Oral Sex?
Teaser: New data show that men are more likely to become infected with oral HPV and are less likely to clear these oral infections. Does this explain the higher incidence of HPV oropharyngeal cancer?

Headlines: Zika in Early Pregnancy May Be More Dire, CDC Suggests
Teaser: The CDC found more fetal brain abnormalties than it expected. Perhaps not surprisingly, the agency cautioned pregnant women today not to attend the summer Olympics in Brazil, epicenter of the Zika outbreak.

Headlines: Obesity, Diabetes Continue to Rise, CDC Survey Shows
Teaser: The National Health Interview Survey has identified troubling findings regarding some health measures and reassuring information about other health measures.

Headlines: Flu Vaccine Far More Effective Than Last Year's, CDC Says
Teaser: The current vaccine has been nearly 60% effective in reducing the risk of getting sick, a far cry from the 18% effectiveness rate reported for the 2014-2015 flu season.

Headlines: HPV Infection Rate Plummets Since Vaccine Introduction
Teaser: The prevalence of human papillomavirus infections among teenage girls in the United States has declined by 64% since the HPV vaccination program was introduced, according to a new study.

Headlines: ESAs Do Not Improve HRQoL in Patients With Anemia and CKD
Teaser: Using erythropoietin-stimulating agents to treat anemia in patients with CKD did not significantly improve health-related quality of life, according to a new study.

Headlines: Fetal Autopsy Report Strengthens Zika-Microcephaly Link
